elements.content: A strongly anisotropic architecture of stacked metal–organic grids, with pores arranged through their eyes, has been revealed for the new coordination polymer Ni­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2­·DMF­·CH3OH­·H2O, where bipy is 4,4′-bipyridine and hip is 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid. This porous crystal, when submerged in various nonpenetrating oils used as the hydrostatic media, displays a negative volume compressibility. This counterintuitive effect results in the zone amorphization injecting the contents of collapsing pores into the retained crystalline portions of the sample. This additional contents of the pores supports the crystalline parts and prevents their amorphization.
elements.clean_text: A strongly anisotropic architecture of stacked metal-organic grids, with pores arranged through their eyes, has been revealed for the new coordination polymer Ni(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅DMF⋅CH3OH⋅H2O, where bipy is 4,4'-bipyridine and hip is 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid. This porous crystal, when submerged in various nonpenetrating oils used as the hydrostatic media, displays a negative volume compressibility. This counterintuitive effect results in the zone amorphization injecting the contents of collapsing pores into the retained crystalline portions of the sample. This additional contents of the pores supports the crystalline parts and prevents their amorphization.

elements.content: A new coordination polymer Ni­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2·DMF·CH3OH·H2O (hereafter AMU-2), where bipy is 4,4′-bipyridine and hip is 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, mimics a negative volume compression, when compressed in oils. This counterintuitive behavior is induced by guest molecules extruded from the collapsed crystal portions into the retained pores of the crystal.
elements.clean_text: A new coordination polymer Ni(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅DMF⋅CH3OH⋅H2O (hereafter AMU-2), where bipy is 4,4'-bipyridine and hip is 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, mimics a negative volume compression, when compressed in oils. This counterintuitive behavior is induced by guest molecules extruded from the collapsed crystal portions into the retained pores of the crystal.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs, also known as porous coordination polymers, PCPs) attract a considerable attention from chemists and materials engineers. These advanced functional materials have rapidly found numerous new applications in catalysis, magnetic, luminescent materials, drug delivery, and sensing. Particularly the gas storage capabilities of MOFs are highly efficient. Owing to the large surface area, adjustable pore size, and tunable pore-surface properties, MOFs are envisaged as ideal storage for clean-energy applications, such as fuel-gases (H2, CH4) storage and CO2 absorbers. The maximized absorption of these gases has been a demanding challenge for designing new porous MOFs. New MOFs architectures are generated mainly through the application of new organic struts of different sizes and shapes, as well as by introducing various functional groups.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs, also known as porous coordination polymers, PCPs) attract a considerable attention from chemists and materials engineers. These advanced functional materials have rapidly found numerous new applications in catalysis, magnetic, luminescent materials, drug delivery, and sensing. Particularly the gas storage capabilities of MOFs are highly efficient. Owing to the large surface area, adjustable pore size, and tunable pore-surface properties, MOFs are envisaged as ideal storage for clean-energy applications, such as fuel-gases (H2, CH4) storage and CO2 absorbers. The maximized absorption of these gases has been a demanding challenge for designing new porous MOFs. New MOFs architectures are generated mainly through the application of new organic struts of different sizes and shapes, as well as by introducing various functional groups.

elements.content: In our search for new types of porous materials, we have modified the conditions of reactions successfully applied for synthesizing the known structural motifs. We are particularly interested in the patterns of square, rectangular, and rhomboidal connections leading to two-dimentional (2D) girds. Such grids of the general formula Me­(Linker1)­(Linker2)­(Ligand1)­(Ligand2) can be further stacked into three-dimentional (3D) architectures, where the third dimension of aggregation is controlled through some kind of cohesion forces, for example, hydrogen bonds between ligands and linkers. The layer MOFs possess new properties associated with the flexibility of 2D grids and “anisotropic solubility” considerably higher for the H-bonds than for the coordination bonds along the 2D grids, while the minimum dimensions of the pores within the gird eyes can be controlled by the conformation and orientation of linkers. This type of stacked grids was realized in piezochroMOF AMU-1, the first strongly piezochromic MOF visibly changing its color.
elements.clean_text: In our search for new types of porous materials, we have modified the conditions of reactions successfully applied for synthesizing the known structural motifs. We are particularly interested in the patterns of square, rectangular, and rhomboidal connections leading to two-dimentional (2D) girds. Such grids of the general formula Me(Linker1)(Linker2)(Ligand1)(Ligand2) can be further stacked into three-dimentional (3D) architectures, where the third dimension of aggregation is controlled through some kind of cohesion forces, for example, hydrogen bonds between ligands and linkers. The layer MOFs possess new properties associated with the flexibility of 2D grids and "anisotropic solubility" considerably higher for the H-bonds than for the coordination bonds along the 2D grids, while the minimum dimensions of the pores within the gird eyes can be controlled by the conformation and orientation of linkers. This type of stacked grids was realized in piezochroMOF AMU-1, the first strongly piezochromic MOF visibly changing its color.

elements.content: Herein we present a new porous metal–organic material Ni­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2, (hereafter AMU-2, where AMU abbreviates Adam Mickiewicz University), involving two different linkers, 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy) and 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid anion (hip), as well as water molecules coordinating Ni cations in 2D grid-like sheets tightly H-bonded into a 3D porous structure (.). We have revealed unprecedented elastic and sorption-elastic properties of this layer crystal at high pressure. It appears that the crystal displays the effect of negative volume compressibility (NVC), which cannot be reconciled with the fundamental thermodynamic requirement, that any substance exposed to increased pressure reduces its volume. In the structures of two other analogous grid MOFs Co­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2­·bipy­·DMSO and Co­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2­·bipy­·DMF reported by He et al., the grids of Co­(II) coordinated by bipy and hip linkers are H-bonded and additionally supported by guest bipy molecules stacked between the bipy linkers oriented approximately parallel to the grids. It will be shown that these features are drastically different from AMU-2 described in this report.
elements.clean_text: Herein we present a new porous metal-organic material Ni(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2, (hereafter AMU-2, where AMU abbreviates Adam Mickiewicz University), involving two different linkers, 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy) and 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid anion (hip), as well as water molecules coordinating Ni cations in 2D grid-like sheets tightly H-bonded into a 3D porous structure (.). We have revealed unprecedented elastic and sorption-elastic properties of this layer crystal at high pressure. It appears that the crystal displays the effect of negative volume compressibility (NVC), which cannot be reconciled with the fundamental thermodynamic requirement, that any substance exposed to increased pressure reduces its volume. In the structures of two other analogous grid MOFs Co(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅bipy⋅DMSO and Co(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅bipy⋅DMF reported by He et al., the grids of Co(II) coordinated by bipy and hip linkers are H-bonded and additionally supported by guest bipy molecules stacked between the bipy linkers oriented approximately parallel to the grids. It will be shown that these features are drastically different from AMU-2 described in this report.

elements.content: (a) Cation Ni2+ octahedrally coordinated by 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (hip); and water molecules in MOF AMU-2; and (b) its block-scheme architecture.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Cation Ni2+ octahedrally coordinated by 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (hip); and water molecules in MOF AMU-2; and (b) its block-scheme architecture.

elements.content: NiNO3 (Sigma-Aldrich), 4,4′-bipy (Sigma-Aldrich), and H2hip (Sigma-Aldrich) were used as supplied without further purification. Single crystals of Ni­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2 were synthesized by the diffusion method: 1 mmol of NiNO3 (0,8720 g) was dissolved in 5 mL of MeOH, and 1 mmol of H2hip (0.5380 g) was added and stirred for 10 min; then the solution was layered carefully on top of the 5 mL bipy–DMF solution (2 mmol 0.9329 g). These two layers were separated with 2 mL of the DMF–MeOH mixture. After 1 week, light-blue prismatic crystals precipitated ().
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of AMU-2

NiNO3 (Sigma-Aldrich), 4,4'-bipy (Sigma-Aldrich), and H2hip (Sigma-Aldrich) were used as supplied without further purification. Single crystals of Ni(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2 were synthesized by the diffusion method: 1 mmol of NiNO3 (0,8720 g) was dissolved in 5 mL of MeOH, and 1 mmol of H2hip (0.5380 g) was added and stirred for 10 min; then the solution was layered carefully on top of the 5 mL bipy-DMF solution (2 mmol 0.9329 g). These two layers were separated with 2 mL of the DMF-MeOH mixture. After 1 week, light-blue prismatic crystals precipitated ().

elements.content: Data were measured at room temperature on a four-circle diffractometer Oxford-Diffraction Xcalibur Eos with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (0.71073 Å) and a CCD detector. The unit-cell dimensions were obtained by fitting observed reflections in CrysAlisPro; the structure was solved by direct methods with Shelxs and refined by last-squares with Shelxl implemented in Olex2. Crystallographic data and experimental details of the structural analyses are summarized in . The H atoms were located according to the molecular geometry and right H2O model was assumed.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Data were measured at room temperature on a four-circle diffractometer Oxford-Diffraction Xcalibur Eos with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (0.71073 Å) and a CCD detector. The unit-cell dimensions were obtained by fitting observed reflections in CrysAlisPro; the structure was solved by direct methods with Shelxs and refined by last-squares with Shelxl implemented in Olex2. Crystallographic data and experimental details of the structural analyses are summarized in . The H atoms were located according to the molecular geometry and right H2O model was assumed.

Selected Crystal Data of AMU-2 Compressed in Oil Daphne 7373: Crystal Symmetry Orthorhombic, Space Group <italic>Pccn</italic>, <italic>Z</italic> = 8 <italic>Z′</italic> = 1<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="tbl1-fn1"></xref> pressure 0.1 MPa 0.08(2) GPa 0.3(2) GPa 0.5(2) GPa 1.0(2) MPa 1.67(2) GPa a (Å) 13.722(2) 13.789(9) 13.530(16) 13.235(18) 12.61(2) 12.23(3) b (Å) 19.1020(17) 19.340(3) 19.337(3) 19.248(3) 19.086(4) 19.025(6) c (Å) 22.516(3) 22.514(2) 22.512(2) 22.459(3) 22.360(3) 22.377(5) volume (Å3) 5895.6(13) 6004(4) 5890(7) 5721(8) 5381(9) 5205(14) D x (g/cm3) 1.105 1.085 1.106 1.139 1.211 1.252

The initial stoichiometry Ni­(hip)­(bipy)­(H2O)2·H2O·CH3OH·DMF assumed for D x .

High-pressure experiments were performed in a Merrill-Bassett diamond-anvil cell (DAC), modified by mounting the diamond anvils directly on the steel supports with conical windows. The gaskets were made of steel foil, 0.3 mm thick, with spark-eroded and preindented 0.4 mm holes. Daphne 7373 oil (of Idemitsu Kosan Co. Ltd.), Fluorinert FC-77 (of 3M), and NVH oil (of MiTeGen LLC) were used as the pressure-transmitting media. The pressure in the DAC was calibrated by the R1 ruby-line shift, measured by a photon-control spectrometer of enhanced resolution, affording an accuracy of 0.02 GPa. The DAC was centered by the gasket-shadow method. The high-pressure structure of AMU-2 has been refined starting from its ambient-pressure model by full-matrix least-squares with SHELXL. The contents of pores in high-pressure structures were treated by the SQUEEZE instruction.
elements.clean_text:
High-Pressure Measurements

High-pressure experiments were performed in a Merrill-Bassett diamond-anvil cell (DAC), modified by mounting the diamond anvils directly on the steel supports with conical windows. The gaskets were made of steel foil, 0.3 mm thick, with spark-eroded and preindented 0.4 mm holes. Daphne 7373 oil (of Idemitsu Kosan Co. Ltd.), Fluorinert FC-77 (of 3M), and NVH oil (of MiTeGen LLC) were used as the pressure-transmitting media. The pressure in the DAC was calibrated by the R1 ruby-line shift, measured by a photon-control spectrometer of enhanced resolution, affording an accuracy of 0.02 GPa. The DAC was centered by the gasket-shadow method. The high-pressure structure of AMU-2 has been refined starting from its ambient-pressure model by full-matrix least-squares with SHELXL. The contents of pores in high-pressure structures were treated by the SQUEEZE instruction.

elements.content: High-pressure powder X-ray diffraction was measured for the samples enclosed in the DAC on a four-circle X-ray diffractometer KUMA-KM04 CCD. The beam was collimated to a diameter smaller than the gasket hole, so the images were not contaminated with the steel gasket rings. The images were recorded for ω rotated ±10° at χ positioned at equal to 0°, 45° and 90°, each at φ = 0° and 180°. The background of images recorded for the samples was accounted for by subtracting the images recorded, at the same positions, for the empty DAC. Then, after the diamonds reflections were removed, the recorded images were integrated to produce I­(2θ) plots in CrysAlisPro.
elements.clean_text:
High-Pressure Powder X-ray Diffraction

High-pressure powder X-ray diffraction was measured for the samples enclosed in the DAC on a four-circle X-ray diffractometer KUMA-KM04 CCD. The beam was collimated to a diameter smaller than the gasket hole, so the images were not contaminated with the steel gasket rings. The images were recorded for ω rotated ±10° at χ positioned at equal to 0°, 45° and 90°, each at φ = 0° and 180°. The background of images recorded for the samples was accounted for by subtracting the images recorded, at the same positions, for the empty DAC. Then, after the diamonds reflections were removed, the recorded images were integrated to produce I(2θ) plots in CrysAlisPro.

elements.content:
Measurements were performed on a PerkinElmer model STA 6000 machine with coupled FT-IR Frontier spectrometer (cf. ).

Powder X-ray Diffraction

PXRD patterns were recorded with a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a Johansson monochromator (λCuKα1 = 1.5406 Å) and a silicon-strip LynxEye detector (cf. ).

FT-IR

spectra of solid state samples (KBr pellets) were collected on a Jasco 4000 FT-IR apparatus in the range from 399 to 4000 cm–1 (cf. ).

Results and DiscussionFramework and Pores in AMU-2

The highly porous AMU-2 crystal of orthorhombic space group Pccn (, ) is built of Ni­(hip)­(bipy)­(H2O)2 grids extending parallel to axes [y, z] and H-bonded along [x]. The grid is formed of the Ni2+ cations linked by hip dianions along direction [y] and by bipy molecules along [z]. The hydrogen bonds OH···O are formed between the hip and water ligands. The coordination octahedron of the Ni2+ cation is only slightly distorted: the Ni–O distance is 2.068(2) Å, Ni–Owater 2.079(2) Å and Ni–N 2.105(2) Å; all O−Ni−N, O−Ni−O, and N−Ni−N angles involving neighboring and opposite ligands are close to 90° and 180°, respectively. The Ni2+ cation is located at Wyckoff special position d. Its symmetry requires that the Ni2+ cation and its bipy ligands lie on the same 2-fold axis parallel to [z]. The pores extend along [x] and they include Wyckoff special positions a and b, both of site symmetry C i , separated by distance a/2. Consequently, all the channel pores in AMU-2 are equivalent and without polar directions nor enantiomorphic preferences ().
elements.clean_text:
Simultaneous Thermal Analysis (STA) with Coupled Fourier Transform-Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR)

Measurements were performed on a PerkinElmer model STA 6000 machine with coupled FT-IR Frontier spectrometer (cf. ).

Powder X-ray Diffraction

PXRD patterns were recorded with a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a Johansson monochromator (λCuKα1 = 1.5406 Å) and a silicon-strip LynxEye detector (cf. ).

FT-IR

spectra of solid state samples (KBr pellets) were collected on a Jasco 4000 FT-IR apparatus in the range from 399 to 4000 cm-1 (cf. ).

Results and Discussion

Framework and Pores in AMU-2

The highly porous AMU-2 crystal of orthorhombic space group Pccn (, ) is built of Ni(hip)(bipy)(H2O)2 grids extending parallel to axes [y, z] and H-bonded along [x]. The grid is formed of the Ni2+ cations linked by hip dianions along direction [y] and by bipy molecules along [z]. The hydrogen bonds OH⋅⋅⋅O are formed between the hip and water ligands. The coordination octahedron of the Ni2+ cation is only slightly distorted: the Ni-O distance is 2.068(2) Å, Ni-Owater 2.079(2) Å and Ni-N 2.105(2) Å;  all O-Ni-N, O-Ni-O, and N-Ni-N angles involving neighboring and opposite ligands are close to 90° and 180°, respectively. The Ni2+ cation is located at Wyckoff special position d. Its symmetry requires that the Ni2+ cation and its bipy ligands lie on the same 2-fold axis parallel to [z]. The pores extend along [x] and they include Wyckoff special positions a and b, both of site symmetry C  i , separated by distance a/2. Consequently, all the channel pores in AMU-2 are equivalent and without polar directions nor enantiomorphic preferences ().

elements.content: Solvent-accessible channel pore in AMU-2, modeled by program MOFomics, with the positions of guest molecules as determined at ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: 2  Solvent-accessible channel pore in AMU-2, modeled by program MOFomics, with the positions of guest molecules as determined at ambient conditions.

elements.content: According to the calculations by program MOFomics, the pores in AMU-2, include two void cavities, the larger about 6.6 Å and smaller 6.0 Å in diameter, separated by a somewhat narrower section about 2 Å long (). Thus, all the channel volume is easily accessible, and the as-prepared crystal in its pores contains DMF, methanol, and water molecules. The DMF guest molecules are released in three stages, at 40, 80, and 164 °C, which can be associated with three cross sections of pores distinguished by the MOFomics calculations (cf. in Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: According to the calculations by program MOFomics, the pores in AMU-2, include two void cavities, the larger about 6.6 Å and smaller 6.0 Å in diameter, separated by a somewhat narrower section about 2 Å long (). Thus, all the channel volume is easily accessible, and the as-prepared crystal in its pores contains DMF, methanol, and water molecules. The DMF guest molecules are released in three stages, at 40, 80, and 164 °C, which can be associated with three cross sections of pores distinguished by the MOFomics calculations (cf.  in Supporting Information).

elements.content: The AMU-2 structure is most rigid along [-Ni-bipy-] linkers aligned along 2-fold axes in direction [z]. The [-Ni-hip-] n strands are more flexible due to the general position of the hip linkers and their wavy modulation in the crystal along [y] (a). At high pressure this sinusoidal feature is straightened and parameter b becomes longer, with initially, to about 0.12 GPa, the negative linear compressibility clearly visible. Above 0.12 GPa the b compression is positive.
elements.clean_text: The AMU-2 structure is most rigid along [-Ni-bipy-] linkers aligned along 2-fold axes in direction [z]. The [-Ni-hip-] n  strands are more flexible due to the general position of the hip linkers and their wavy modulation in the crystal along [y] (a). At high pressure this sinusoidal feature is straightened and parameter b becomes longer, with initially, to about 0.12 GPa, the negative linear compressibility clearly visible. Above 0.12 GPa the b compression is positive.

elements.content: Crystal framework of Ni­(hip)­(bipy)­(H2O)2 projected along crystal directions: (a) [x]; (b) [z]; (c) [y], with the solvent-accessible channels drawn for the probing-sphere radius of 1.2 and 0.2 Å steps. ,
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal framework of Ni(hip)(bipy)(H2O)2 projected along crystal directions: (a) [x]; (b) [z]; (c) [y], with the solvent-accessible channels drawn for the probing-sphere radius of 1.2 and 0.2 Å steps. ,

elements.content: The crystal is softest along direction [x], owing to the hydrogen bonds, weaker than the coordination bonds Ni–O and Ni–N. Moreover, the compression along [x] strongly depends on the rotation of hip linkers. The hip and bipy rotations have little or no effect on the crystal compression along directions [y] and [z]; however these rotations can confine or widen up the cross section of the pores. Thus, the voids volume strongly depends on the easiest-compressed direction [x] as well as on the rotations and conformations of the linkers.
elements.clean_text: The crystal is softest along direction [x], owing to the hydrogen bonds, weaker than the coordination bonds Ni-O and Ni-N. Moreover, the compression along [x] strongly depends on the rotation of hip linkers. The hip and bipy rotations have little or no effect on the crystal compression along directions [y] and [z]; however these rotations can confine or widen up the cross section of the pores. Thus, the voids volume strongly depends on the easiest-compressed direction [x] as well as on the rotations and conformations of the linkers.

elements.content: The grids are connected by two types of OH···H bonds. Both of them are included in the cyclomer of O···H–O–H···O···H–O bonds between carboxylate oxygen O41, water H2O1W, carboxylate oxygen O2, and hydroxyl O51H (1symmetry code −1/2 + x, 1 – y, 1/2 – z, ). The graph descriptor for this cyclomer is R3 3(11).
elements.clean_text: The grids are connected by two types of OH⋅⋅⋅H bonds. Both of them are included in the cyclomer of O⋅⋅⋅H-O-H⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅H-O bonds between carboxylate oxygen O41, water H2O1W, carboxylate oxygen O2, and hydroxyl O51H (1symmetry code -1/2 + x, 1 - y, 1/2 - z, ). The graph descriptor for this cyclomer is R3 3(11).

elements.content: Lengths of H-bonds in AMU-2 as a function of pressure. The inset shows the H-bonded cyclomer of one water molecule and two hip anions between the neighboring grids. The highlights joining the points are guiding the eye only.
elements.clean_text: 4  Lengths of H-bonds in AMU-2 as a function of pressure. The inset shows the H-bonded cyclomer of one water molecule and two hip anions between the neighboring grids. The highlights joining the points are guiding the eye only.

elements.content: The compression of AMU-2 () confirms the stiffness of the grids and softness of their H-bonded spacing. When compressed hydrostatically in Fluorinert FC-77, Daphne 7373 oil, and NVH oil, the Ni­(hip)­(bipy)­(H2O)2·H2O­·CH3OH­·DMF crystal initially (starting from 0.1 MPa to about 0.1 GPa) increases its volume by about 2%, which indicates that some transport increasing the content of pores in the bulk of crystal takes place. This is a most surprising result for a crystal compressed in nonpenetrating oils, built of molecules considerably larger than the cross section of the pores. This unprecedented property of AMU-2 has been discussed separately below. Above 0.1 GPa the crystal compression becomes positive, and at 0.3 GPa the crystal volume becomes comparable to that at 0.1 MPa, and at still higher pressure the volume strongly decreases, to about 90% at 1 GPa. As predicted, the least affected by pressure are directions [z] and [y] along the grid; the lengthening and subsequent shortening of direction [y] are due to the changing positions of hip linkers, and the strongest changes along [x] are due to the compression of H-bonds and rotations of the hip linkers. It is characteristic that the crystal volume initially increases mainly due to the elongation of b, whereas the volume compression above 0.12 MPa is practically regulated by the linear shortening of a.
elements.clean_text:
Negative Compression of AMU-2

The compression of AMU-2 () confirms the stiffness of the grids and softness of their H-bonded spacing. When compressed hydrostatically in Fluorinert FC-77, Daphne 7373 oil, and NVH oil, the Ni(hip)(bipy)(H2O)2⋅H2O⋅CH3OH⋅DMF crystal initially (starting from 0.1 MPa to about 0.1 GPa) increases its volume by about 2%, which indicates that some transport increasing the content of pores in the bulk of crystal takes place. This is a most surprising result for a crystal compressed in nonpenetrating oils, built of molecules considerably larger than the cross section of the pores. This unprecedented property of AMU-2 has been discussed separately below. Above 0.1 GPa the crystal compression becomes positive, and at 0.3 GPa the crystal volume becomes comparable to that at 0.1 MPa, and at still higher pressure the volume strongly decreases, to about 90% at 1 GPa. As predicted, the least affected by pressure are directions [z] and [y] along the grid; the lengthening and subsequent shortening of direction [y] are due to the changing positions of hip linkers, and the strongest changes along [x] are due to the compression of H-bonds and rotations of the hip linkers. It is characteristic that the crystal volume initially increases mainly due to the elongation of b, whereas the volume compression above 0.12 MPa is practically regulated by the linear shortening of a.

elements.content: Relative changes in the unit-cell volume (top) and parameters (bottom) for AMU-2 isothermally compressed in oils: Daphne 7373, NVH, and Fluorinert FC-77. The top insets show the visible compression of the sample crystal and the pressure dependence of the intensity of reflection 220: the bottom insets show the layer 1kl of the diffraction data of AMU-2 measured at 0.08 and 1.67 GPa.
elements.clean_text: 5  Relative changes in the unit-cell volume (top) and parameters (bottom) for AMU-2 isothermally compressed in oils: Daphne 7373, NVH, and Fluorinert FC-77. The top insets show the visible compression of the sample crystal and the pressure dependence of the intensity of reflection 220: the bottom insets show the layer 1kl of the diffraction data of AMU-2 measured at 0.08 and 1.67 GPa.

elements.content: The negative volume compressibility (NVC) to 0.1 GPa is surprising, counterintuitive, and cannot be reconciled with the strict thermodynamic requirement that pressure must reduce the volume of any compound. The only explanation of the NVC is the transport of some additional compounds pushed into the bulk of the crystal, either its pores or isolated voids. However, in our experiments the crystals stored in a dry environment for weeks were later submerged in oils, the large molecules of which block the entrance to pores. Therefore, no transport of the fluid from outside to the bulk of crystal through its surface could occur. This well-known sealing property of oils was often evidenced for various types of porous materials. After the initial series of experiments with Daphne 7373, in order to eliminate the possibility that some of its components are capable of penetrating into pores of AMU-2, we have repeated the compression measurements in Fluorinert FC-77 and NVH oil. Moreover, the microscopic observations of the compressed samples revealed their visible compression along [y] ( and ).
elements.clean_text: The negative volume compressibility (NVC) to 0.1 GPa is surprising, counterintuitive, and cannot be reconciled with the strict thermodynamic requirement that pressure must reduce the volume of any compound. The only explanation of the NVC is the transport of some additional compounds pushed into the bulk of the crystal, either its pores or isolated voids. However, in our experiments the crystals stored in a dry environment for weeks were later submerged in oils, the large molecules of which block the entrance to pores. Therefore, no transport of the fluid from outside to the bulk of crystal through its surface could occur. This well-known sealing property of oils was often evidenced for various types of porous materials. After the initial series of experiments with Daphne 7373, in order to eliminate the possibility that some of its components are capable of penetrating into pores of AMU-2, we have repeated the compression measurements in Fluorinert FC-77 and NVH oil. Moreover, the microscopic observations of the compressed samples revealed their visible compression along [y] ( and ).

elements.content: Schematic illustration of the “zone-collapse” effect in AMU-2; (a) the initial stage of the sample immersed in a nonpenetrating hydrostatic medium at 0.1 MPa; (b) the transport of guests from the collapsed to crystalline parts.
elements.clean_text: 6  Schematic illustration of the "zone-collapse" effect in AMU-2; (a) the initial stage of the sample immersed in a nonpenetrating hydrostatic medium at 0.1 MPa; (b) the transport of guests from the collapsed to crystalline parts.

elements.content: We have connected the puzzling NVC of AMU-2 in nonpenetrating liquids with the observation of significantly decreasing intensity of X-ray reflections () and with the clear pattern of stripes clearly visible on the crystal faces (010) and (001) perpendicular to direction [x]. It is plausible that these stripes originate from a collapse of the crystal portions parallel to the Ni­(hip)­(bipy)­(H2O)2 grids. Furthermore, microscopic observation of the compressed sample shows that it shrinks along direction [x] by about 30% at 1 GPa, whereas the diffraction measurements show that the corresponding unit-cell dimension a shrinks by about 9% (). It means that a considerable portion of the crystal collapsed along direction [x] much stronger than the compression in the remaining part responsible for the diffraction data, testifying that the crystal compression is much smaller than the visually observed size reduction of the sample. The collapse concerns mainly the softest H-bonded connections between the grids and is likely to induce shear strains of subsequent layers at random directions. Consequently, the translational symmetry along [x] is lost, and the collapsed regions become amorphisized. This is consistent with the considerably reduced intensity of X-ray reflections in high-pressure experiments ( inset and in Supporting Information). These reflections are diffracted on the sample portions which have not collapsed and retain their crystallinity.
elements.clean_text:
Zone-Collapse Model

We have connected the puzzling NVC of AMU-2 in nonpenetrating liquids with the observation of significantly decreasing intensity of X-ray reflections () and with the clear pattern of stripes clearly visible on the crystal faces (010) and (001) perpendicular to direction [x]. It is plausible that these stripes originate from a collapse of the crystal portions parallel to the Ni(hip)(bipy)(H2O)2 grids. Furthermore, microscopic observation of the compressed sample shows that it shrinks along direction [x] by about 30% at 1 GPa, whereas the diffraction measurements show that the corresponding unit-cell dimension a shrinks by about 9% (). It means that a considerable portion of the crystal collapsed along direction [x] much stronger than the compression in the remaining part responsible for the diffraction data, testifying that the crystal compression is much smaller than the visually observed size reduction of the sample. The collapse concerns mainly the softest H-bonded connections between the grids and is likely to induce shear strains of subsequent layers at random directions. Consequently, the translational symmetry along [x] is lost, and the collapsed regions become amorphisized. This is consistent with the considerably reduced intensity of X-ray reflections in high-pressure experiments ( inset and  in Supporting Information). These reflections are diffracted on the sample portions which have not collapsed and retain their crystallinity.

elements.content: Another consequence of the collapsed structure is that the volume of pores is considerably reduced, and their guest contents are pushed out along the channels to the pores within the crystalline regions. This increased contents of pores initially “inflates” the crystalline portions. We have observed the increased volume of the compressed sample by X-ray diffraction experiment, because only the crystalline “inflated” portions of the sample diffract. At still higher pressure, above 0.1 GPa, the transport of the guests contents along the pores is slowed and stopped, and the crystal resumes a “conventional” compression of its volume. In this pressure range, the “inflated” pores counteract the external pressure and prevent the collapse of the crystalline regions. Such an effect of pressure-induced guests preserving the sample crystallinity was observed in zeolites.
elements.clean_text: Another consequence of the collapsed structure is that the volume of pores is considerably reduced, and their guest contents are pushed out along the channels to the pores within the crystalline regions. This increased contents of pores initially "inflates" the crystalline portions. We have observed the increased volume of the compressed sample by X-ray diffraction experiment, because only the crystalline "inflated" portions of the sample diffract. At still higher pressure, above 0.1 GPa, the transport of the guests contents along the pores is slowed and stopped, and the crystal resumes a "conventional" compression of its volume. In this pressure range, the "inflated" pores counteract the external pressure and prevent the collapse of the crystalline regions. Such an effect of pressure-induced guests preserving the sample crystallinity was observed in zeolites.

elements.content: The compression of AMU-2 in nonpenetrating oils can be termed as a “zone-collapse” effect. The framework material, with its pores sealed off by large molecules of oil, at some points collapses under the external pressure, which triggers the transport of guest molecules pushed to the crystalline (not collapsed) regions nearby. In this manner the material is modified by an increased content of the guests generating a higher internal pressure in the pores, capable of compensating for the effect of the external pressure and preventing the structure from collapsing. However, the formation of such “enhanced” crystalline regions depends on the collapsed zones, triggering the transport of the guest molecules and externally generating the pressure in the preserved parts.
elements.clean_text: The compression of AMU-2 in nonpenetrating oils can be termed as a "zone-collapse" effect. The framework material, with its pores sealed off by large molecules of oil, at some points collapses under the external pressure, which triggers the transport of guest molecules pushed to the crystalline (not collapsed) regions nearby. In this manner the material is modified by an increased content of the guests generating a higher internal pressure in the pores, capable of compensating for the effect of the external pressure and preventing the structure from collapsing. However, the formation of such "enhanced" crystalline regions depends on the collapsed zones, triggering the transport of the guest molecules and externally generating the pressure in the preserved parts.

elements.content: In order to better understand this mechanism of “zone-collapse” compression, we have performed the compression of AMU-2 in glycerin and the mixture CH3OH/DMF (1:1 mol). It occurs that the single-crystal samples can be kept in this mixture with no visible changes of their quality; however, a small increase of pressure of about 0.1 GPa causes the disintegration of crystals. It confirms that transport of guest molecules in AMU-2 is very sensitive to relatively small changes of external pressure.
elements.clean_text: In order to better understand this mechanism of "zone-collapse" compression, we have performed the compression of AMU-2 in glycerin and the mixture CH3OH/DMF (1:1 mol). It occurs that the single-crystal samples can be kept in this mixture with no visible changes of their quality; however, a small increase of pressure of about 0.1 GPa causes the disintegration of crystals. It confirms that transport of guest molecules in AMU-2 is very sensitive to relatively small changes of external pressure.

elements.content: It appears that the “zone-collapse” in AMU-2 is associated with its specific structure, built of grids, securing the flow of guests along the pores, and “soft” intergrids connections, which are sensitive to the pressure within and without the pores.
elements.clean_text: It appears that the "zone-collapse" in AMU-2 is associated with its specific structure, built of grids, securing the flow of guests along the pores, and "soft" intergrids connections, which are sensitive to the pressure within and without the pores.

elements.content: schematically illustrated the compression of this porous material. The overall crystal compressibility, βV, β V = − 1 / V · d V / d p = − 1 / V ( V − V 0 ) / d p can be decomposed into the compressibility components of the framework and the pores: β V = − 1 / ( V F + V P ) d ( V F + V P ) / d p where V is the crystal volume, V F is the framework volume, and V p is the volume of pores: V = V F + V P. Irrespective of the pores contents, the volume of the framework, V F (nodes and linkers), is hardly changed. If we assume that dV F ≪ dV p, can be rewritten in the form: β V ≈ − 1 / ( V F + V P ) ( d V P / d p )

Irrespective of the pores contents, the volume of the framework, V F (nodes and linkers), is hardly changed. If we assume that dV F ≪ dV p,  can be rewritten in the form: 3       β   V   ~ - 1 /  (   V   F   +   V   P   )   ( d   V   P   / d p )

elements.content: For the crystal isolated from its environment (a thermodynamic closed system), βV must be either zero or positive. Open systems allow the transport of matter, either to or out of the pores; the uptake of guests can lead to a negative βV (positive dV p in ), although it describes the simultaneous events of compression and changing composition of the crystal. Naturally, the required positive βV applies to the high-pressure behavior of materials of fixed stoichiometry. Porous material AMU-2 does not fulfill the condition of fixed stoichiometry, even when nonpenetrating hydrostatic fluids are used. The observed volume increase at higher pressure is a consequence of the applied method of X-ray diffraction probing only the crystalline part of the AMU-2 sample and not the amorphized zones.
elements.clean_text: For the crystal isolated from its environment (a thermodynamic closed system), βV must be either zero or positive. Open systems allow the transport of matter, either to or out of the pores; the uptake of guests can lead to a negative βV (positive dV p in ), although it describes the simultaneous events of compression and changing composition of the crystal. Naturally, the required positive βV applies to the high-pressure behavior of materials of fixed stoichiometry. Porous material AMU-2 does not fulfill the condition of fixed stoichiometry, even when nonpenetrating hydrostatic fluids are used. The observed volume increase at higher pressure is a consequence of the applied method of X-ray diffraction probing only the crystalline part of the AMU-2 sample and not the amorphized zones.

elements.content: The DAC chamber can be considered as a closed thermodynamic system, except the thrust increasing pressure being generated outside. Thus, the main subsystems in the DAC chamber in an compression experiments are the hydrostatic fluid (oils) and the sample crystal, of initial stoichiometry Ni­(hip)­(bipy)­(H2O)2­·H2O­·CH3OH­·DMF. Under pressure, this initially uniform crystal, due to the transport of guests, differentiates into two other subsystems: amorphous and “inflated” crystalline parts.
elements.clean_text: The DAC chamber can be considered as a closed thermodynamic system, except the thrust increasing pressure being generated outside. Thus, the main subsystems in the DAC chamber in an compression experiments are the hydrostatic fluid (oils) and the sample crystal, of initial stoichiometry Ni(hip)(bipy)(H2O)2⋅H2O⋅CH3OH⋅DMF. Under pressure, this initially uniform crystal, due to the transport of guests, differentiates into two other subsystems: amorphous and "inflated" crystalline parts.

elements.content: Assuming an average atomic volume in molecular crystal of 18 Å3/atom at 0.1 GPa, an additional amount of guest equal to about six additional atoms (e.g., two methanol and two water molecules) is pushed into one unit cell of crystalline part from the collapsed zones.
elements.clean_text: Assuming an average atomic volume in molecular crystal of 18 Å3/atom at 0.1 GPa, an additional amount of guest equal to about six additional atoms (e.g., two methanol and two water molecules) is pushed into one unit cell of crystalline part from the collapsed zones.

elements.content: The effect of pressure-enforced adsorption of liquids in porous materials was evidenced in zeolites as well as in metal–organic frameworks. The solvent-triggered structural transformations of MOFs have been reported recently. In those high-pressure experiments, various simple molecular fluids (water, methanol, ethanol, etc.) and their mixtures were used instead of nonpenetrating pressure media. In those experiments two competing effects of compression of the system (sometimes called “hyper-filling” or “overhydration”) and of adsorption of the fluid inside the porous material are observed. The uptake of guests increases the elastic moduli and diminishes compressibility of porous materials, and also improves the resistance to their onset of pressure-induced amorphization.
elements.clean_text: The effect of pressure-enforced adsorption of liquids in porous materials was evidenced in zeolites as well as in metal-organic frameworks. The solvent-triggered structural transformations of MOFs have been reported recently. In those high-pressure experiments, various simple molecular fluids (water, methanol, ethanol, etc.) and their mixtures were used instead of nonpenetrating pressure media. In those experiments two competing effects of compression of the system (sometimes called "hyper-filling" or "overhydration") and of adsorption of the fluid inside the porous material are observed. The uptake of guests increases the elastic moduli and diminishes compressibility of porous materials, and also improves the resistance to their onset of pressure-induced amorphization.

elements.content: It appears that the elastic properties of AMU-2 are significantly different from those of analogous grid MOFs Co­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2­·bipy­·DMSO and Co­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2­·bipy­·DMF, due to their contents of bipy guests blocking the pores and additionally supporting these structures perpendicular to the grids, by the stacking interactions between the pyridine rings of bipy guests and bipy linkers. Moreover, one of the bipy rings protrudes into the pore, obscuring its aperture. These properties of MOFs Co­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2­·bipy­·DMSO and Co­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2­·bipy­·DMF require an experimental investigation, by compressing these compounds in nonpenetrating fluids.
elements.clean_text: It appears that the elastic properties of AMU-2 are significantly different from those of analogous grid MOFs Co(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅bipy⋅DMSO and Co(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅bipy⋅DMF, due to their contents of bipy guests blocking the pores and additionally supporting these structures perpendicular to the grids, by the stacking interactions between the pyridine rings of bipy guests and bipy linkers. Moreover, one of the bipy rings protrudes into the pore, obscuring its aperture. These properties of MOFs Co(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅bipy⋅DMSO and Co(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2⋅bipy⋅DMF require an experimental investigation, by compressing these compounds in nonpenetrating fluids.

elements.content: The architecture of H-bonded metal–organic grids in AMU-2 displays its new qualities resulting from the “zone-collapse” effect. Owing to this property AMU-2 is capable of self-adjusting its discriminated portions to the external stimuli. In thermodynamic terms, a closed system of one uniform phase under the hydrostatic pressure breaks into two phases: the collapsed amorphous phase extruding its guest molecules; and the crystalline phase “inflated” by the additional guest molecules pumped in from the collapsed pores. Thus, the counterintuitive negative volume compression is the observation (by X-ray diffraction) of an open thermodynamic system of the crystalline part internally supported by the transport of additional guests pumped in from collapsed zones. To our knowledge this property has not been described for any uniform crystalline phase. Although it is partly analogous to the classical coexistence of phases (e.g., vapor with liquid; liquid and solid; or two solid phases), in AMU-2 the equilibrium is regulated by the transport of guest molecules in the pores. Therefore, AMU-2 can be considered as a molecular machine consisting of two units: a pressure generator (the collapsed part) inflating and supporting the crystalline part. This intelligent-material feature of AMU-2 offers a part of the compressed sample a method of circumventing (by coupling its stoichiometry to external pressure) the limitation of the most fundamental thermodynamic principle of positive βV. This is an additional new quality compared to those of uniformly transforming crystals, capable of undergoing all-positive, negative-linear, and negative-area , compression.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The architecture of H-bonded metal-organic grids in AMU-2 displays its new qualities resulting from the "zone-collapse" effect. Owing to this property AMU-2 is capable of self-adjusting its discriminated portions to the external stimuli. In thermodynamic terms, a closed system of one uniform phase under the hydrostatic pressure breaks into two phases: the collapsed amorphous phase extruding its guest molecules; and the crystalline phase "inflated" by the additional guest molecules pumped in from the collapsed pores. Thus, the counterintuitive negative volume compression is the observation (by X-ray diffraction) of an open thermodynamic system of the crystalline part internally supported by the transport of additional guests pumped in from collapsed zones. To our knowledge this property has not been described for any uniform crystalline phase. Although it is partly analogous to the classical coexistence of phases (e.g., vapor with liquid; liquid and solid; or two solid phases), in AMU-2 the equilibrium is regulated by the transport of guest molecules in the pores. Therefore, AMU-2 can be considered as a molecular machine consisting of two units: a pressure generator (the collapsed part) inflating and supporting the crystalline part. This intelligent-material feature of AMU-2 offers a part of the compressed sample a method of circumventing (by coupling its stoichiometry to external pressure) the limitation of the most fundamental thermodynamic principle of positive βV. This is an additional new quality compared to those of uniformly transforming crystals, capable of undergoing all-positive, negative-linear, and negative-area ,  compression.

cln_elements.content: NiNO3 (Sigma-Aldrich), 4,4′-bipy (Sigma-Aldrich), and H2hip (Sigma-Aldrich) were used as supplied without further purification. Single crystals of Ni­(bipy)­(hip)­(H2O)2 were synthesized by the diffusion method: 1 mmol of NiNO3 (0,8720 g) was dissolved in 5 mL of MeOH, and 1 mmol of H2hip (0.5380 g) was added and stirred for 10 min; then the solution was layered carefully on top of the 5 mL bipy–DMF solution (2 mmol 0.9329 g). These two layers were separated with 2 mL of the DMF–MeOH mixture. After 1 week, light-blue prismatic crystals precipitated ().
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of AMU-2

NiNO3 (Sigma-Aldrich), 4,4'-bipy (Sigma-Aldrich), and H2hip (Sigma-Aldrich) were used as supplied without further purification. Single crystals of Ni(bipy)(hip)(H2O)2 were synthesized by the diffusion method: 1 mmol of NiNO3 (0,8720 g) was dissolved in 5 mL of MeOH, and 1 mmol of H2hip (0.5380 g) was added and stirred for 10 min; then the solution was layered carefully on top of the 5 mL bipy-DMF solution (2 mmol 0.9329 g). These two layers were separated with 2 mL of the DMF-MeOH mixture. After 1 week, light-blue prismatic crystals precipitated ().

metadata.title:
Zone-Collapse Amorphization
Mimicking the Negative
Compressibility of a Porous Compound
